thread.title: Kyle Schwarber calls encased home run ball 'great honor'
thread.title_full: Kyle Schwarber calls encased home run ball 'great honor' - Chicago Tribune

author: Colleen Kane
title: Kyle Schwarber calls encased home run ball 'great honor'
text:
Kyle Schwarber called it “pretty cool” that his home run ball from Tuesday’s National League Division Series clincher will be encased atop the right-field video board at Wrigley Field for the remainder of the playoffs.
But the Cubs rookie also wasn’t going to get too caught up in the hoopla surrounding the ball, which included helicopters hovering over the field Wednesday to try to catch glimpses of the ball that came to rest beneath the small ‘I’ in the Budweiser sign.
The Cubs, after all, were at Wrigley Field for batting practice Thursday to prepare for their NL Championship Series contest Saturday against the Mets or Dodgers.
“It’s a great honor,” Schwarber said. “Wrigley Field has such great history. For it to stay up there for however long it does -- I don’t know how long they plan on keeping it up there -- it will be cool.
“It’s fun. But I’m not focused on a home run ball. I’m focused on our next series, just being able to get our bodies right.”
Schwarber said he doesn’t often watch where home run balls land, so he didn’t know what had happened to his ball until later that night.
“Once you hit it, and you know it’s gone, you watch it for a little bit, and then you just put your head down and start running,” Schwarber said. “You really don’t follow where it ends up.”
Kyle Schwarber hits a Schwarbomb Kyle Schwarber crushes a homer in the seventh inning of the Cubs' NLDS-clinching victory. (MLB/YouTube/Tom Comings)
Kyle Schwarber crushes a homer in the seventh inning of the Cubs' NLDS-clinching victory. (MLB/YouTube/Tom Comings)
See more videos Cubs manager Joe Maddon called the encasement of the ball atop the board “pure genius.”
“The way tradition and lore are dealt with around here, that could withstand the test of time,” Maddon said. “Now they definitely have to keep that scoreboard intact, right? If there’s any consideration to do anything differently, you’ve got to keep it there now.”
Starlin Castro said he thought the best part of Schwarber’s homer was that Schwarber told Dexter Fowler in the outfield he would hit one earlier in the inning.
“He told them he’d hit that homer, and he did it, and I think it’s pretty awesome,” Castro said.
Schwarber said he was just joking around, even if the comments turned prophetic.
“It was just ball talk,” Schwarber said. “We were just talking out there, and I was just joking with him, and I said, ‘Hey, I think I’m going to hit a home run.’ I’m not going to go up there and point.”
